name: Chicago Community Bond Fund
mission: Chicago Community Bond Fund pays bond for people in Cook County, Illinois. Through a revolving fund, CCBF supports individuals whose communities cannot ...
theoryOfChange: By paying bond, CCBF restores the presumption of innocence and enables recipients to remain free while fighting their cases, while simultaneously advocating for systemic abolition of the money bond system.

dimension_explanations.alignment: With an alignment score of 19/50, the organization is noted for its focus on cause urgency and advocacy within the legal system [1].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates high financial accountability with a Charity Navigator score of 96.0/100 and a total revenue of $751,883 [1]. While its impact score of 32/50 reflects a focus on capacity building and systemic advocacy, its 90.2% program expense ratio indicates a strong commitment to its revolving fund and public education programs [2].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Chicago Community Bond Fund provides critical financial support to individuals in Cook County by paying bond for those who cannot afford it.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 90.2%, ensuring the vast majority of funds go directly to services [1]
Strong financial health with 47.4 months of working capital available [1]
Excellent fundraising efficiency, spending only $0.07 to raise every $1 [1]
baseline_narrative.summary: The Chicago Community Bond Fund (CCBF) operates a revolving fund to support individuals in Cook County, Illinois, whose communities cannot afford the cost of bond [1]. In addition to direct financial assistance, the organization focuses on public education and advocacy regarding the impact of the cash bond system [2]. Donors can contribute to these efforts through various giving methods to support the fund's mission of ending money bail [3].

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize systemic legal reform and want to support a sustainable, revolving fund model within the US criminal justice system.
donor_motivations: Value high financial transparency and low overhead
Interested in social justice and pretrial reform
Prefer supporting local, community-based initiatives in Chicago
Want their donation to be recycled through a revolving fund
giving_considerations: The organization focuses on advocacy which has long-term rather than instant results
Large capital reserves suggest the organization is not in an immediate cash crisis
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking to fulfill zakat obligations or those looking for international humanitarian relief.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects a clear strategic roadmap but a lack of third-party evaluations or cost-per-beneficiary data.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: CCBF uses a revolving fund to provide immediate relief from bond while using that momentum to advocate for the total abolition of money bail.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that the revolving fund is effectively preventing pretrial harm and contributing to policy shifts.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: While reserves are high, declining revenue trends suggest a need for sustained donor support to maintain advocacy levels.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by its <cite id="2">revolving fund model</cite> specifically targeting Cook County.

strengths.detail: The organization directs a <cite id="7">90.2% program expense ratio</cite> toward its mission, significantly exceeding industry benchmarks for direct service delivery.
CCBF holds a <cite id="4">96/100 overall rating from Charity Navigator</cite> and has earned a <cite id="10">Gold Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite>.
The charity demonstrates lean operations, spending only <cite id="11">$0.07 to raise every $1</cite> in contributions.

strengths_deep_dive: The Chicago Community Bond Fund's financial health is anchored by its <cite id="12">47.4 months of working capital</cite>, providing a massive buffer for long-term sustainability. This stability is paired with a <cite id="13">90.2% independent board of directors</cite>, ensuring objective oversight of its <cite id="14">$751,883 in annual revenue</cite>. Furthermore, the organization's <cite id="15">documented theory of change</cite> provides a clear roadmap for how its revolving fund and advocacy efforts lead to systemic legal reform.
rich_narrative.summary: The Chicago Community Bond Fund (CCBF) is a specialized nonprofit organization dedicated to providing critical financial support to individuals in Cook County by <cite id="1">paying bond for those who cannot afford it</cite>. Operating primarily through a <cite id="2">revolving fund model</cite>, the organization addresses the immediate humanitarian crisis of pretrial incarceration while simultaneously engaging in <cite id="3">public education and advocacy</cite> to reform the cash bond system. The organization maintains a <cite id="4">96/100 overall score from Charity Navigator</cite>, reflecting a high degree of institutional trust and financial transparency. Despite a <cite id="5">3-year revenue CAGR of -26.5%</cite>, CCBF remains financially robust, holding <cite id="6">$7,164,767 in total assets</cite> as of its most recent filings. Its operations are characterized by an exceptional <cite id="7">90.2% program expense ratio</cite>, ensuring that every dollar of revenue is directed toward its core mission of <cite id="8">ending money bail and supporting communities</cite> impacted by the legal system. By revolving its bond funds, CCBF creates a sustainable cycle of impact where <cite id="9">returned bond money is reinvested</cite> to help additional individuals, maximizing the long-term utility of every donation.
